approach:

approach:

objective: add dollars and cents with renaming.
approach:
To begin this lesson, show students the Explore task and ask them to determine what the question is asking. Tell them your friend believes he can just add all three items together to find the answer. It is important they read all of the information in the question. Ask students how they can solve this type of question; there are three items, but he only bought two. Should we just guess which two and stop? Should we try all combinations of two? How can we organise our thinking so that we are certain to try all the possible combinations? Allow students to speak to each other about this and suggest some methods to organise their thinking.
As in the Master section, when students begin to add, structure their thinking by placing 'bars' around the monetary amounts to facilitate the bar modelling strategy, which will be used later in the chapter. Arrange the coins from the greatest to the lowest value, and ask students if they notice anything about your diagram. As they are adding the different amounts together, prompt them by asking whether it is possible to make a dollar out of any of the coins during the addition. When they look at the toy plane and the mini figure, tell them your friend says he can make a dollar by exchanging some coins for smaller ones. Is this true? How can they be sure? objective: subtract dollars and cents without renaming.
approach:
To begin this lesson, provide students with coins and notes and ask them to give themselves $7.40. Then show them the Explore task and ask how they can solve the problem. Allow them to exchange and discard money. Tell them your friend said you could find the answer by physically removing the cost of the poster from the amount of money you started with. Is this true? How do you take 10c away from a 20c coin?
Prompt students to understand that the 20c coin is the same as two 10c coins. Can 10c be taken away now? Allow them to try this and show each other. Structure their learning by helping them to uncover all three methods of subtraction by posing the Master questions to them in order.
During Guided Practice, students are exposed to a variety of ways that subtraction can be worded in a question. For the first question, point out the key words 'less than' and explain this must mean subtraction. In Example 2, point out the words 'price difference'. Incorrectly suggest this must mean add the different prices together. Allow them to explore this. What does adding do? What does subtraction do? For the third question, discuss what the act of buying something is (an exchange of your money for an item that means your money is reduced, not increased).

objective: subtract dollars and cents with renaming.
approach:
To begin this lesson, show students the Explore task and allow them some time to work out the solution. Tell them your friend said that using number bonds is helpful. He said he would break apart the dollars to help him solve this problem. Would this work? How can we find out? objective: tell time using a.m./p.m.
approach:
To begin this lesson, put the terms 'ante meridiem' and 'post meridiem' in front of the class. Ask them to discuss what they think these terms might mean. Tell them that meridiem has something to do with midday. Let them discuss this and continue to drop hints until they arrive at the idea that a.m. and p.m. come from the Latin words for 'before midday' and 'after midday'.
Now show students the Explore task and let them discuss the question with one another. Ask them how they would write 08:15 in the morning. What would the hour hand look like at that time? Why? Where would the minute hand be? Why? Show them Master 2 and allow them to discuss their thoughts.

objective: tell time to the minute.
approach:
To begin this lesson, provide students with clocks. Then show them the Explore task and ask them if they can replicate the time shown in the picture on their own clock. What time does the clock show? How do they know? How can they be sure? Count on together with students in fives starting from 9 o'clock to 9:20, and then count on in 1-minute intervals until 9:24. Tell them your friend says that if you count up all of the small markings you get to 60. Is this true? What does the 60 stand for?
Next, ask students what they notice about the hour hand on their clocks as they move the minute hand. Is there a relationship or does the hour hand just switch numbers at the end of 60 minutes? Allow them to discuss with their partners how the hour hand moves within a period of an hour. For example, when the minute hand shows half past, the hour hand is halfway between hours. Show students the images in Master 3 and 4, and then ask them to describe the positions of the hour hands and explain the difference.
During Guided Practice, students are telling time to the minute. Ask them how they can tell the time to the minute without counting every small marking.

objective: measure and compare time in seconds.
approach:
To begin this lesson, ask students to work in pairs to complete an activity with a stopwatch. Ask them to set it to countdown from 20 seconds. Alternatively, use an online countdown timer for the whole class. Ask students to focus on how long 20 seconds is.
First, ask students to find out how many times they can clap in 20 seconds. Then ask them what other activities they could try to do in 20 seconds. Show them the activities suggested in Master. Help them to draw a table to record the time it takes for each activity. Introduce the abbreviation 's' for seconds. Work through the Master tasks with students and complete the chart. During Master 4, ask students what other activities they think could be completed in the same time it took the swimmers to swim 50 m.
Remind students that the digits to the right of the seconds indicate part of a second. They will learn about this in future year groups.
Students may have the opportunity to use analogue stopwatches. Show them a stopwatch that has started and ask them to decide what the increments stand for. Agree that the stopwatch is showing the time in seconds. Tell students that they will be learning why it is labelled to 60 in future lessons. There may be students who know that 60 seconds is equal to 1 minute.

Show the class Master 1 and discuss what is shown on the stopwatch and the phone stopwatch. Ask them to read the times shown. Guide them to see how seconds are displayed in digital form. Ask students to discuss who took longer to draw a rectangle and by how much.
Next, show them Master 2 and ask them to guess how long it took Holly to get across the playground. Tell them your friend said it took Holly 14 minutes to get across the playground. Is this true? How else can we know that this is not correct? (Is it reasonable to think that it would take someone 14 minutes to get across the playground?)

objective: measure time in seconds.
approach:
To begin the lesson, show students an analogue clock with a second hand. Ask them to look at the second hand and compare it with the hour and minute hands. How can we differentiate the second hand from the minute and hour hands? Show students how to read time using the second hand. Guide them to realise that the measurement in seconds using the analogue clock is the same for the minute hand and second hand, and then ask them to count in seconds using the clock face. They can count in blocks of 5 seconds.
Then use the clock to conduct an experiment to count how many times students can deal a pack of cards in 15 seconds. Students should use the second hand on the clock to measure 15 seconds. Divide students into two groups; one group will focus on watching the time, and the other group will count the number of cards dealt. One card dealt is counted when the card is placed in front of the student. Complete the experiment four times with the groups switching roles each time. objective: interpret and present data using bar charts.
approach:
To begin this lesson, show students the Explore task. Ask them questions about the graph, such as what each red cube represents and the number of each coloured pencils. Tell them that in a bar graph we don't need to count the number as we would in the picture graph; instead we can tell the number by reading the 'scale'. objective: count in tenths.
approach:

objective: add fractions with the same denominator within 1 whole.
approach:
To begin this lesson, show students the Explore task and discuss the number of parts the cake has been divided into. How many pieces have strawberry icing? How many pieces have chocolate icing? Therefore, we can see that 3 pieces of cake with strawberry icing and 5 pieces of cake with chocolate icing make a total of 8 pieces. Ask students how we write 3 out of 8 pieces. Tell them we read 3/8 as 3 eighths. What about 5 out of 8 pieces? How do we read 5/8? Point out that 3/8 and 5/8 will make 8/8.
Ask students what they notice about the denominators and numerators. Guide them to see that the denominator tells us the total number of equal parts a whole has been divided into; that is why it remains the same whether we count the strawberry or chocolate parts. The numerator tells us the number of equal parts we are counting, and that is why it is 3 when we count the strawberry parts and 5 when we count the chocolate parts.
Provide students with small paper squares in two different colours and ask them to combine them to make 8 pieces. For each pattern, ask them to write the two fractions that will make 8/8. Show them that we can also use number bonds to present the pairs of fractions.

objective: add fractions with the same denominator within 1 whole.
approach:
To begin this lesson, provide students with a piece of paper that has been divided into fifths. Tell them to pretend that this is a sushi roll. Show them the Explore task and ask them to share the bar in the same way. Ask them how they will do this; allow them to shade the parts and cut them out, etc. Then ask them to display what they have done and show you how much of the sushi roll has been eaten by each character.
Ask them to write the fraction for the amount of sushi each character has eaten. Guide them to see that as the sushi roll has been divided into 7 parts, each part should be written as 1/7 and read as 1 seventh. Then ask them to find how much sushi both of them have eaten altogether. Show them we can add the two fractions: 1/7 and 3/7 to find the total amount of sushi eaten, which is 4/7.
Guide students to conclude that adding fractions with the same denominator is the same as adding whole numbers. We do not add the denominator because it only tells us how many equal parts a whole has been divided into. We add the numerators because they tell us the number of equal parts we are counting.

objective: subtract fractions with the same denominator within 1 whole.
approach:
To begin this lesson, provide students with an enlarged copy of the sushi roll in the Explore task and discuss the problem with them. There are two parts to the problem. The first part of the problem tells us that Hannah has already taken 1 piece of the sushi roll, and the picture shows the amount of sushi left. The second part tells us that Ravi is going to take 5 more pieces of sushi.
Ask students how many pieces the sushi roll was divided into at first. How can we tell? Since Hannah has taken 1 piece and there are 8 pieces left, this tells us that there were 9 pieces at first. Ask students what the fraction is for 1 piece of sushi roll, and tell them that 1/9 should be read as 1 ninths. What fraction of the sushi has Hannah taken? 1/9 should be read as 1 ninths. What fraction of the sushi roll is left after Ravi has taken his share? 3/9 should be read as 3 ninths.
Ravi then takes 5 pieces. What fraction of the sushi roll is 1 piece? There are 8/9 of the sushi roll remaining. After he takes 5/9, what fraction of sushi roll is left? Ask students if they know which calculation to do to find the fraction of sushi left. We need to use subtraction to find the fraction of sushi roll left: 8/9 – 5/9 = 3/9.
Go through Master 2, subtracting 3/7 from 6/7. Guide students to conclude that subtracting fractions with the same denominator is the same as subtracting whole numbers (as in addition). We do not subtract the denominator as it tells us how many parts a whole has been divided into. We subtract the numerators as they tell us the number of parts we are counting.
During Guided Practice, students are subtracting fractions with the same denominator.

objective: recognise and show equivalent fractions.
approach:
To begin this lesson, provide students with a number of paper strips of equal length. Ask them to take a piece of paper and fold it into 2 equal parts, shading in 1 part. Tell them the shaded part is their piece. Ask them what fraction they have, prompting them to see it is 1 half. Write 1/2 on the board and place a strip of paper divided into 2 parts beside it.
Now show students the Explore task and ask them to discuss what is meant by this problem. How can we have more parts, but still use the same strip of paper? Is there something we can do to increase the number of parts here? Prompt students to fold the paper more times. Is it possible to turn the 2 parts into 4 parts? Allow them time to attempt this. Now that we have 4 parts, what should we call each part? We call them 1 quarter. Ask students if they know how to write the fraction for 1/4, and then write it on the board and place a strip of paper divided into 4 parts beside it.
Ask students to compare the two strips of paper — compare each part and compare the whole. Ask them to tell you what they observe. The whole has remained the same, but the number of parts has changed. Lead students to see that 1/2 is now 2/4 by putting the two strips one above the other to compare. Guide them to see that although the whole has been divided into more equal parts, the whole has not changed. We call these fractions equivalent because they are equal, so 1/2 = 2/4. Ask them to try finding other equivalent fractions of 1/2.
During Guided Practice, students are expected to divide the images into smaller parts, paying close attention to which number is being given: the numerator (the number of parts that will be shaded) or the denominator (the number of parts that the whole has been divided by).

approach:

Then represent the fractions using a bar model, as shown in Master 1. We can see that 1/10 is less than 9/10. Therefore, Charles has less pancake than Tama. Help students to see that when the denominators are the same, we only need to compare the numerators to see which fraction is greater.
For the next part of the task, ask students if there are other ways for Tama to take more of the pancake than Charles. What if Tama gets 7 pieces? What would the fraction be for Tama? What about Charles? Show students Master 3 and ask students what fractions are shown for Charles and Tama. Both get 5/10, therefore they get the same amount. Ask students to write 5/10 in its simplest form. 5/10 = 1/2.

objective: recognise, find and write fractions of a discrete set of objects.
approach:

objective: identify perpendicular lines.
approach:
To begin this lesson, ask students if they remember what a right-angle checker is. Show them the Explore task and ask them to use their checker (ruler) to identify the right angles in the picture in Explore. Ask them to show you which two lines meet to make the right angles. Explain that these two lines have a special name. Ask students if they know what the lines are called. Tell them they are called perpendicular lines. Can you identify any perpendicular lines in the classroom using your right-angle checkers? Guide students to realise that if they can find a right angle, they can find perpendicular lines.
Show students Master 3. Lead them to see that lines can be labelled using letters. In the example, we can say that line AB is perpendicular to line CD. Ask students what makes the lines perpendicular in Master 3 and 4, and what makes them not perpendicular. Are there things that must always be in place for lines to be perpendicular? Can short lines be perpendicular? Can thick lines be perpendicular? What matters most?
During Guided Practice, students are identifying perpendicular lines in a picture, angles and shapes.

objective: identify parallel lines.
approach:
To begin this lesson, show students the Explore task and ask them to discuss what they notice about the picture and the lines in the picture. Ask them how they would describe the beams going along the page in comparison to the beams pointing up. Are the lines perpendicular? What about the two beams pointing up? Are they perpendicular? What type of lines are they? Tell students that parallel lines are lines that do not make an angle, as they never meet, no matter how long they are. Let them know that perpendicular lines and parallel lines are special lines because of their unique characteristics. Ask them to identify these lines in the classroom.
Show students Master 2 and how to use arrow heads to indicate when lines are parallel.
During Guided Practice, students are identifying parallel lines in pictures, diagrams and shapes. For Example 2, ask them if they can prove that the lines EF and GH are not parallel. Illustrate that when the lines are extended, EF and GH will eventually meet to form an angle. Show them that even when lines AB and CD are extended, they will never meet. During Guided Practice 3, ask students to explain why they think certain lines are parallel. It can be difficult to check if lines are parallel 'by eye' so it is important students are able to justify their thinking by referring to the properties of parallel lines.
formative_assessment: understand that parallel means two lines that never meet.

objective: identify horizontal and vertical lines.
approach:
To begin this lesson, show students the Explore task. Ask them to apply what they have learnt about special lines to describe the sides of the flip chart. Would it help if they label the lines? Show them how you would label the sides of the picture using A, B, C and D, as shown in Master 1. Allow them time to come up with descriptions of the lines.
Explain to students that there are other ways to describe lines. Tell them that we can also use the term 'vertical' to describe the lines. 'Vertical' lines are perpendicular to the floor. Can you identify the lines in the picture that are perpendicular to the floor? How many of these lines are there? Show them that the sides of the picture; the lines AC and BD, can be extended to show that they are perpendicular to the floor. What else can we say about these lines? Guide students to see that they are also parallel as they will never meet no matter how long they are extended.
Then ask students to describe lines AB and CD. They are parallel to each other. Guide students to see that they are also parallel to the floor, and tell them these lines are called 'horizontal' lines.
During Guided Practice, students are identifying horizontal and vertical lines in the classroom and in a picture.

objective: measure the perimeter of 2D shapes.
approach:

objective: calculate the perimeter of 2D shapes.
approach:
To begin this lesson, show students the Explore task. What is the perimeter of one tile? How can we calculate the perimeter of the rectangle? Allow students some time to discuss and gather all their methods.
Then work through the methods shown in Master with the class. Master 1 is a method that students are familiar with, e.g. to find each side of the rectangle, and then add all the 4 sides together. Tell them there is a shortcut to finding the perimeter, but we must first remember the side properties of a rectangle. Tell students look at the sides of the rectangle, and ask them if they notice a pattern in the lengths of the sides. Guide students to see that 2 sides are 3 cm and the other 2 sides are 4 cm. So, if we know the length of each of these sides, we can simply add them and multiply by 2 to find the perimeter. Direct students' attention to the sides of the rectangle as you explain this method.
During Guided Practice, students are calculating the perimeter of objects on a 1-cm square grid and measuring shapes. Encourage them to use the methods they have learnt.

calculate the perimeter of a figure by adding all the sides.

objective: measure the perimeter of 2D shapes.
approach:
To begin this lesson, show students the Explore task and ask them how many ways they are able to calculate the perimeter of the square. Ask them if they know the property of the sides of a square (also remind students that a square is a special type of rectangle). Remind them that all the 4 sides have the same length. Tell them your friend knows three ways to calculate the perimeter (using addition, using both addition and multiplication, and using only multiplication). Is this possible? Can you show all three ways? Is there another way? Then ask them how many ways they are able to calculate the perimeter of the rectangle. Ask them if they know the property of the sides of a rectangle. Remind them that are 2 pairs of equal length sides. Ask them if it is possible to calculate the perimeter of a rectangle in the same ways they found for a square.
Guide students to see that they can use addition to add all the 4 sides to find the perimeter of the square. They can also add 2 sides of the square and then multiply this by 2. How about using the property of the sides of a square? Since all the sides are the same length, if we know 1 side we just need to multiply this by 4 to find the perimeter. Show the students the rectangle and mark the 2 pairs of opposite sides. What do they notice about the lengths of the opposite sides? As there are 2 pairs of equal length sides we can multiply the lengths of the 2 sides by 2.
During Guided Practice, students are finding the perimeter of different shapes using multiple methods (including addition, addition and multiplication, and strictly multiplication).
